Hello! How are you doing? Today’s tip is about spending One-on-One Time with our children.
It’s free and fun. It makes children feel loved and secure, and also increases their confidence and self-esteem!
Here are 6 tips to make it a success:
Step 1. Spend at least 5 minutes with each child
Even 5 minutes a day of quality time makes a big difference. It can be at the same time each day so your children look forward to it.
Step 2. Give your child your full attention
Make sure you will not be interrupted. Switch off the TV and give your full attention to your child while setting aside other things for now. Put your phone on silent. It will show your child, they are important.
Step 3. Let your child choose the activity
Ask your child what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?”
Choosing builds their self-confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t OK with COVID-19 rules, then this is a chance to talk with them about this. If your child cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like, like reading a book or building blocks together.
Step 4. Follow your child's lead
Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative.
Step 5. Use words to describe what your child is doing
Listening to your child is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what your child is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!
Step 6. Have fun!
One-on-One Time with your child can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after playing with your child.
Congratulations! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Quality time with your children is the best gift that you can ever give them.

Hi! I just wanted to thank you for making this commitment to improve the life of your children. It shows you really care!
Today's Parenting Tip is all about Praise. We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.
Praise works for our children, too. When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves!
Here are 3 simple steps to get it right:
Step 1. Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.
Step 2. Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, Sam,' instead of 'Good job.'
Step 3. Praise with enthusiasm. Really mean it when you say it!
Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Try to find 3 things that you can praise your children for every day. You can also praise other adults in your household, too. Notice how they respond!

Hello! Today's Parenting Tip is about how we can involve our children in creating consistent household rules.
Household rules can help children feel secure and keep them safe from potential dangers both inside the house and in the community. They also help children to know what kind of behaviour is expected from them.
Here are 6 simple tips on how you can make household rules with your children and teens:
1. Involve your child in establishing household rules.
2. Make your household rules clear, positive and specific.
3. Make sure your child understands the reasons why you are establishing a household rule.
4. Make your household rules fair and realistic (just like instructions).
5. Praise and simple rewards such as a hug and a kiss can help support your child in following a household rule.
6. Add only 1 household rule at a time.
Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember when you involve your children in establishing household rules, they are more likely to follow them. Try to be consistent and positive.

Hello! Most parents struggle when their children have temper tantrums and other demanding behaviours.
Here are 6 steps, you can try to make it happen less often!
1. Try to redirect your child's attention
When they start demanding or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity and praise them!
2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours, like whining, demanding, showing off, and tantrums. If we respond or give in to these behaviours, children learn that this will get them attention and what they want.
3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.
Ignoring means removing physical and verbal attention. Take a Pause, stay calm, and be aware of what your child is doing.
4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
Having a tantrum is difficult for your child too. As soon as your child has calmed down, involve them in a positive activity. You can talk about what happened later, but right now your child needs love.
5. Be consistent when ignoring
Your child’s response might get worse when you first start using ignore. They are trying to test you! Continue to ignore the behaviour!
Over time, your child will learn that it no longer works.
6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times
If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!
Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. But if you are patient, it really works. You can do this!

Hello! Today's tip is about how we can help our children learn how to solve problems and conflicts.
Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:
Here are 6 basic steps of problem solving with your teen:
1. Identify the problem.
2. Think of possible solutions.
3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be.
4. Choose one solution.
5. Try it out!
6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution.
We can also teach our children the same steps.
When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems.
Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.
Try to find solutions together:
1. Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings.
2. Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective.
3. Thank your teen for being open and trusting you
Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Helping your teen learn how to solve problems will be something they will take with them the rest of their lives. What a gift!
